metadata.title: A Minireview on Nanocatalysts for Electrocatalytic Oxidation of Ethanol

metadata.abstractText: The use of ethanol as a fuel in direct alcohol fuel cells depends not only on its ease of production from renewable sources, but also overcomes the challenges of storage and transportation. In an ethanol-based fuel cell, highly active electrocatalysts are demanded to break the C-C bond in ethanol for its complete oxidation at lower overpotentials, aiming at increase of cell performance, ethanol conversion rates, and fuel efficiency. Within the past decades, the development of wet-chemistry methods stimulates a blossom of research in catalyst design, reactivity tailoring, and mechanistic investigation, which creates great opportunities to achieve efficient oxidation of ethanol. In this minireview, we summarize the nanomaterials tested as electrocatalysts for ethanol oxidation reaction in acid or alkaline environment. We focus on the nanomaterials mainly synthesized using wet-chemistry methods in recent years, with particular attention on the relationship between the chemical and physical characteristics of the catalysts, e.g., catalyst composition, morphology, structure, degree of alloying, and presence of oxides or supports, and their activity for ethanol electrooxidation. As potential alternatives for noble metals, non-noble metal catalysts for ethanol oxidation are also briefly reviewed. We also make some perspectives in last section in designing efficient electrocatalysts so as to provide the readers insights for further enhancing the catalytic performance.
